#Text=NOTE.
#Text=--When cooking products in pint or half-pint jars deduct three or
#Text= four minutes from the time given above.
#Text=When cooking in two-quart jars
#Text= add 3 or 4 minutes to time.
#Text=The estimates given are for quart jars.
#Text=CHAPTER IV
#Text=
#Text= VEGETABLES
#Text=
#Text=
#Text= It is practical to can all vegetables, even such difficult ones as
#Text= corn, peas and beans, by the cold-pack method of canning without using
#Text= any preservatives, if you will follow all directions, instructions and
#Text= the time-table accurately.
#Text=Vegetable canning is a little more
#Text= complicated than fruit canning.
#Text=TOMATOES
#Text=
#Text= Every one likes canned tomatoes.
#Text=In many homes more tomatoes are
#Text= canned than any other product.
#Text=The housewife uses them for soups, for
#Text= sauces and for seasoning many meat dishes.
#Text=Some women say: "I can
#Text= preserve everything but tomatoes.
#Text= jars and in mushy vegetables.
#Text=For this reason you should have in your equipment a lifter with which
#Text= you can lift out the hot jars without the hands touching them.
#Text=If you
#Text= use a rack with wire handles this answers the same purpose.
#Text=This "flat sour," which is not at all dangerous from the standpoint of
#Text= health, must not be confused with the botulinus bacteria, which is an
#Text= entirely different thing.
#Text="Flat sour," perfectly harmless, appears often with inexperienced
#Text= canners.
#Text=Botulinus, harmful, appears rarely.
#Text=You need not be at all
#Text= alarmed about eating either "flat sour" or botulinus, because the odor
#Text= from spoiled goods is so distasteful--it really resembles rancid
#Text= cheese--that you would never get a spoon of it to your mouth.
#Text=If you are debating whether this jar or that jar of soup or vegetables
#Text= is spoiled, do not _taste_ the contents of the jar.
#Text=_Smell_ it.
#Text=Tasting might poison you if you happened on the botulinus bacteria,
#Text= which is so rare it need alarm no one; whereas smelling is perfectly
#Text= safe.
#Text=TIME-TABLE FOR SOUPS
#Text=

#Text= GRAY SOUP WITHOUT STOCK

#Text=jelly, or can the juice for use as a beverage, for flavoring ice cream
#Text= or some form of cooking.
#Text=By employing this test, sugar can often be reduced, and thus the jelly
#Text= texture will be fine, less rubbery and the flavor will be better.
#Text=After the fruit has been selected and prepared as usual by washing,
#Text= stemming, and so forth, it is ready to be heated in an acid-proof
#Text= kettle.
#Text=With juicy fruits use just enough water to prevent
#Text= burning--about one cup of water to every four or five quarts of fruit.
#Text=The juicy fruits are currants, raspberries, and so forth.
#Text=With less
#Text= juicy fruits, as apples or quinces, use enough water to cover, or
#Text= follow the rule, half as much water as fruit.
#Text=Use the cores, skins and
#Text= seeds; these improve the flavor and color of the jelly.
#Text=Berries can be mashed.
#Text=Heat the fruit slowly in a covered kettle,
#Text= stirring once in a while to obtain an even cooking.
#Text=When the simmering
#Text= point is reached, crush the fruit with a well-soaked wooden masher.
#Text=When the fruit is tender or has a transparent appearance, it is ready
#Text= to strain.
#Text=and then boil it.
#Text=After it is boiled, remove all meat and make a mock
#Text= turtle stew or ragout.
#Text=Prepare the tripe as for table use and then
#Text= can.
#Text=After the soup stock is made and the bones are cracked for a second
#Text= cooking, the bones need not be thrown away.
#Text=You can dry them, run them
#Text= through a bone crusher and either feed them to the chickens or use
#Text= them for fertilizer.
#Text=In this way not a particle of the dressed animal
#Text= is wasted.
#Text=Here are a few ways to utilize the cuts that are really "left-overs."
#Text=GOULASH
#Text=
#Text= 2 Pounds of meat scraps which can consist of beef, veal or pork.
#Text= 2 Ounces of any fat.
#Text= 2 Onions chopped fine.
#Text= 1 Stalk celery, cut in small pieces.
#Text= 2 Carrots.
#Text=2 Cups tomatoes either canned or fresh.
#Text= 1 Bay leaf.
#Text= 6 Whole cloves.
#Text= 6 Peppercorns.
#Text= 1 Blade mace or a little thyme or both.
#Text=A little flour.
#Text= 1 Tablespoonful chopped parsley.
#Text=Salt and paprika to taste.
#Text=Cut the meat into one inch squares and roll in flour.
#Text=Melt the fat in
#Text= the frying pan, add the vegetables (onions, celery, carrots) and brown
#Text= lightly: add the meat and brown.
#Text=Stir with a spoon or fork to prevent
#Text= burning.
#Text=When browned empty into a pan.
#Text=Put the bay leaf, cloves, peppercorns, mace and thyme into a
#Text= cheesecloth bag and add to the meat, add tomatoes.
#Text=Cover with soup
#Text= stock or water and simmer 45 minutes if it is going to be canned.
#Text=If
#Text= for immediate use, 2 hours will be necessary to thoroughly cook it.
#Text=Remove the spices, season with salt, paprika and the chopped parsley.
#Text=You can add Worcestershire sauce or soy sauce if desired.
#Text=Use only
#Text= small quantities as these sauces are very strong in their distinctive
#Text= flavor.
#Text=Put hot mixture into cans and sterilize.
#Text=If the different spices are not at hand a good goulash can be made by
#Text= using the meat, fat, onions, tomatoes, flour, salt and pepper and
#Text= omitting the rest of the recipe.
#Text=LIVER SAUSAGE
#Text=
#Text= Beef, veal, or hog liver.
#Text=Remove the membrane and cut away the large
#Text= blood vessels.
#Text=Soak in water 1 to 2 hours to draw out blood.
#Text=Boil
#Text= until done.
#Text=When cooled put through a food chopper or grate finely.
#Text=Take half as much boiled fat pork as liver.
#Text=Divide this fat into two
#Text= portions; chop one portion into one-quarter inch cubes; pass the other
#Text= portion through the food chopper; mix all together thoroughly; add
#Text= salt, ground cloves, pepper, and a little grated onion to taste.
#Text=A
#Text= little thyme and marjoram may be added to suit taste.
#Text=(For a liver
#Text= weighing 1½ pounds add ¾ pounds fat pork, 3 to 4 teaspoonfuls salt, ½
#Text=from your own tin-canned products than from tin-canned food bought at
#Text= the store.
#Text=Most canned foods if in a spoiled condition readily show
#Text= this condition by the swelling of the can or by odor or taste.
#Text=Canned
#Text= foods showing such evidences of decomposition should not be used.
#Text=Certain foods which are high in protein, such as meats, peas, beans
#Text= and fish products, may undergo decomposition without making this
#Text= condition obvious to the senses.
#Text=It is essential, therefore, that the
#Text= greatest care be taken to subject such products to proper preparation
#Text= and ample processing.
#Text=It should be remembered that canned foods, after
#Text= opening the containers, should be treated as perishable products and
#Text= should be handled with the same precautions that are applied when
#Text= fresh products are being used.
#Text=ADVANTAGES OF CANS
#Text=
#Text= Many housewives ask, "Why can in tin when we have always used glass
#Text= jars?"
#Text=There are many advantages in canning in tin which we can well
#Text= consider.
#Text=There is no breakage as in glass; you can handle the tin
#Text=cans as carelessly as you choose and you will not hear a snap or crack
#Text= indicating a lost jar.
#Text=Furthermore, tin cans are easier to handle not
#Text= only in canning but in storing.
#Text=The expense each year of new tin covers or new tin cans is no more
#Text= than the purchase of new rubbers and the replacement of broken glass
#Text= jars.
#Text=Furthermore, one big advantage of tin over glass is that tin
#Text= cans can be cooled quickly by plunging them into cold water
#Text= immediately upon removal from the canner, and thus the cooking is
#Text= stopped at the proper moment.
#Text=The product is consequently better in
#Text= form and flavor than when the cooking is prolonged, as it must be in
#Text= glass jars.
#Text=Many women like the large openings of cans because they
#Text= can make better packs than when using narrow-necked jars.
#Text=If you do not care to bother with the soldering you can purchase a
#Text= safe and simple device that will do the work for you.
#Text=This device is
#Text= called a tin-can sealer.
#Text=With a sealer no soldering is necessary.
#Text=Even an inexperienced person, by following directions carefully, can
#Text= seal a can as well as an experienced one.
#Text=The sealed cans look exactly
#Text= like those purchased at the store.
#Text=Two or three cans a minute can be
#Text=
#Text= Flat-sour often causes annoyance to beginners in canning some
#Text= vegetables, such as corn, peas, beans and asparagus.
#Text=These canned
#Text= foods may show no signs of spoilage and yet when the can is opened the
#Text= product may have a sour taste and a disagreeable odor.
#Text=This
#Text= "flat-sour" is not harmful and must not be confused with "botulinus,"
#Text= which is harmful.
#Text=However, the taste and odor are so disagreeable you
#Text= will have no desire to eat "flat-sour" canned goods.
#Text=This trouble can be avoided if you will use fresh products, that is,
#Text= those which have not been allowed to wilt or stand around the shops
#Text= for several days, and will blanch, cold-dip, and pack one jar of
#Text= product at a time, and place each jar in the canner as it is packed.
#Text=The first jars in will not be affected by the extra cooking.
#Text=When the
#Text= steam-pressure canner is used the jars or cans may be placed in the
#Text= retort and the cover placed into position but not clamped down until
#Text= the retort is filled.
#Text=TROUBLES WITH CORN
#Text=minutes as the canning is."

#Text=And in
#Text= addition there is a third objection to drying: I want my prepared

column1: #Text= food ready to use on a minute  '  s notice.
#Text= your canned stuff.
#Text=These
#Text= terms are used more or less interchangeably when applied to foods from
#Text= which the moisture has been removed.
#Text=In a general way, however,
#Text= "evaporated" products are those from which the moisture has been
#Text= removed through the agency of artificial heat; dried fruit is that
#Text= which has been exposed to the heat of the sun, though not infrequently
#Text= the term is applied to products handled in the evaporator.
#Text=The other
#Text= terms are commonly applied to products that have been evaporated by
#Text= one of the various patented processes in which equipment of some
#Text= special design has been used.
#Text=To avoid any confusion we will use the general term "dried" for all
#Text= products that have enough of the water removed to prevent bacterial
#Text= action, but which still retain the maximum food value, color and
#Text= flavor of the original product.
#Text=And that is what we want to accomplish
#Text= when we attempt to dry.
#Text=How are we to remove the water and still retain food value, color and
#Text=flavor?
#Text=There are three principal methods by which we can do this.
#Text=First, by artificial heat.
#Text=Drying by artificial heat is done in the
#Text= oven or on top of a cookstove or range, in trays suspended on the
#Text= stove or in a specially constructed dryer built at home or purchased.
#Text=Second, by the sun.
#Text=Sun drying is done either out of doors in the sun,
#Text= under glass in sun parlors, or the products are hung in the attic
#Text= where the sun has free access.
#Text=Third, satisfactory drying may be done by an air blast from an
#Text= electric fan.
#Text=Of course any one of these may be used alone or two different methods
#Text= may be combined.
#Text=You can start a product on the stove and finish it in
#Text= the sun, or _vice versa._
#Text=
#Text= The simplest and yet the most effective drying may be done on plates
#Text= or dishes placed in the oven.
#Text=It may be done on the back of the
#Text= kitchen stove with these same utensils while the oven is being used
#Text= for baking.
#Text=In this way left-overs and other bits of food may be dried
#Text=
#Text= Green Tomatoes.
#Text=Green tomatoes should be packed whole and prepared
#Text= as cucumbers.
#Text=The dill and spice may be added if desired.
#Text=Beets.
#Text=Beets must be scrubbed thoroughly and packed whole.
#Text=If peeled
#Text= or sliced before being fermented the beets lose considerable color and
#Text= flavor.
#Text=Beet Tops and Turnip Tops.
#Text=These should be washed thoroughly and
#Text= packed into the container without being cut up.
#Text=Peas.
#Text=Green peas should be shelled and packed in the same way as
#Text= string beans.
#Text=It is advisable to use fairly small containers for peas,
#Text= so that the quantity opened up will be used before it has a chance to
#Text= spoil.
#Text=Corn.
#Text=Husk and clean the silk from the corn; wash and place the ears
#Text= on end in the jar, packing the jar nearly full.
#Text=Pour the brine over
#Text= the ears; add cover and weights.
#Text=Fermented corn has a sour taste,
#Text= which may not be relished if the corn is eaten alone.
#Text=For this reason
#Text=it will be preferable in most cases to preserve corn by canning,
#Text= drying or by salting without fermentation.
#Text=Fermented corn, however,
#Text= may be used in the preparation of some dishes, such as chowders,
#Text= omelets, and so forth, where its flavor will be masked to some extent
#Text= by the other ingredients.
#Text=To some people this peculiar acid taste of
#Text= fermented corn is not at all objectionable.
#Text=Salting Without Fermentation.
#Text=In this method the vegetables are
#Text= packed with enough salt to prevent fermentation or the growth of
#Text= yeasts or molds.
#Text=The vegetables preserved most satisfactorily by this
#Text= method are dandelions, beet tops, turnip tops, spinach, kale, chard,
#Text= cabbage, cauliflower, string beans, green peas and corn.
#Text=The following
#Text= directions should be followed:
#Text=
#Text= The vegetables should be washed, drained and weighed.
#Text=The amount of
#Text= salt needed will be a quarter of the weight of the vegetables.
#Text=Kegs or
#Text= crocks make satisfactory containers.
#Text=Put a layer of vegetables about
#Text= an inch thick on the bottom of the container.
#Text=Cover this with salt.
#Text=Continue making alternate layers of vegetables and salt until the
#Text= container is almost filled.
#Text=The salt should be evenly distributed so
